title: Ladinian
text:
The Ladinian is a <a href="stage%20%28stratigraphy%29">stage</a> and <a href="age%20%28geology%29">age</a> in the <a href="Middle%20Triassic">Middle Triassic</a> <a href="series%20%28stratigraphy%29">series</a> or <a href="epoch%20%28geology%29">epoch</a>. It spans the time between <a href="annum">Ma</a> and ~237 Ma (million years ago). The Ladinian was preceded by the <a href="Anisian">Anisian</a> and succeeded by the <a href="Carnian">Carnian</a> (part of the <a href="Late%20Triassic">Upper or Late Triassic</a>).
The Ladinian is coeval with the <a href="Falangian">Falangian</a> regional stage used in <a href="China">China</a>.
Stratigraphic definitions.
The Ladinian was established by Austrian geologist <a href="Alexander%20Bittner">Alexander Bittner</a> in 1892. Its name comes from the <a href="Ladin%20language">Ladin people</a> that live in the <a href="Italy">Italian</a> <a href="Alps">Alps</a> (in the <a href="Dolomites">Dolomites</a>, then part of <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>).
The base of the Ladinian Stage is defined as the place in the stratigraphic record where the <a href="ammonite">ammonite</a> species "<a href="Eoprotrachyceras">Eoprotrachyceras curionii</a>" first appears or the first appearance of the conodont "<a href="Budurovignathus%20praehungaricus">Budurovignathus praehungaricus</a>". The global reference profile for the base (the <a href="GSSP">GSSP</a>) is at an <a href="outcrop">outcrop</a> in the <a href="river%20bed">river bed</a> of the <a href="Caffaro%20%28river%29">Caffaro</a> river at <a href="Bagolino">Bagolino</a>, in the <a href="province%20of%20Brescia">province of Brescia</a>, northern <a href="Italy">Italy</a>. The top of the Ladinian (the base of the Carnian) is at the first appearance of ammonite species "<a href="Daxatina">Daxatina canadensis</a>".
The Ladinian is sometimes subdivided into two subages or substages, the Fassanian (early or lower) and the Longobardian (late or upper). The Ladinian contains four ammonite biozones, which are evenly distributed among the two substages:
